content: The "Wellness and Prevention Act of 2007" emphasizes the importance of preventive medicine in reducing healthcare costs and improving public health. It highlights the need for more public health professionals and increased focus on preventive methods to address chronic conditions. The Act also aims to provide loan payment assistance for preventive medicine physicians to strengthen the preventive medicine workforce. The "Wellness and Prevention Act of 2007" emphasizes preventive medicine's importance in reducing healthcare costs and improving public health. It provides loan payment assistance of up to $20,000 for eligible preventive medicine physicians who receive board certification in preventive medicine between fiscal years 2008 and 2012. The "Wellness and Prevention Act of 2007" authorizes appropriations for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 to carry out the provisions outlined in the act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. SEC. 4. WELLNESS PROGRAM EMPLOYER CREDIT. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section for a wellness program employer credit. The wellness program employer credit under section 38 allows eligible employers to receive a credit of 25% of expenses for developing and implementing a qualified wellness program. The credit is capped at $200 per qualified employee. Eligible employers must maintain accurate records of employee participation in preventive services and programs. A qualified wellness program is defined as a program that meets specific criteria set forth in the section. A qualified wellness program for eligible employers includes health risk assessments, preventive services, counseling sessions, and seminars on various topics like smoking, obesity, and stress management. A qualified wellness program for eligible employers covers topics such as nutrition, substance abuse, depression, mental health, heart disease, and maternal and infant health. Qualified employees must be full-time employees participating in the employer's wellness program by engaging in at least 2 annual preventive services or programs. The section discusses the requirements for a qualified wellness program for eligible employers, including conducting a health risk assessment. The provision will not apply after December 31, 2012. Conforming amendments are made to Section 38(b) and the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. The section introduces a new wellness program participant credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. The section introduces a new wellness program participant credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. A credit of $200 is allowed against the tax for the taxable year for a qualified employee who is a full-time employee and a qualified participant in the employer's wellness program. A qualified participant must participate in at least 2 annual preventive services or programs and undergo a health risk assessment as determined by the employer. A qualified wellness program for eligible employers includes health risk assessments, preventive services recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, and counseling sessions on smoking, obesity, stress management, and physical fitness. The text chunk discusses the requirements for an eligible employer to develop and implement a qualified wellness program focusing on various health aspects such as physical fitness, nutrition, substance abuse, mental health, heart disease, and maternal and infant health. The employer must keep accurate records of employee participation in preventive services and programs. This section does not apply after December 31, 2012. Part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code is amended by inserting a new item after section 25D. Section 25E introduces a wellness program participant credit, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007.
